newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Indebted Russia to decide on Paris Club membership.
newsitem.headline: Indebted Russia to decide on Paris Club membership.

text.p: Russia, better known as a debtor than as a creditor state, will decide by June whether to join the Paris Club of creditor nations, Deputy Finance Minister Mikhail Kasyanov said on Monday.
"It will be clear within two months," Kasyanov told Reuters. "In any case it will be clear before the June G-7 or G-8 meeting in Denver."
Representatives of the Group of Seven leading industrial countries meet on June 20-22, and Russian President Boris Yeltsin will also join the talks.

Russia, which inherited responsibility for both the assets and the liabilities of the former Soviet Union, is owed about $132 billion by Soviet-era debtors including Vietnam, Ethiopia, Yemen, Cuba and Iraq.
It has rescheduled most of its own Soviet-era debts and borrowed some $20 billion in its own right, mostly from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
Most Soviet-era loans were to so-called friendly states, extended for political reasons rather than for economic ones.

Moscow currently receives just $1-2 billion a year -- half of it in goods -- and officials have given up hope of getting some of the money back. "It is less than one tenth of what we should receive," Kasyanov said.
He said membership of the Paris Club could improve the terms Russia received from its country debtors.

Countries owing Russia $37 billion already have agreements with the club or are in talks with it and Russia would expect to receive the same deal as other creditors. "We have to agree with the Paris Club how much to discount the $37 billion," he said.
"We realise that the price of Russia's assets is lower than the assets of other Paris Club members, but the question is how much lower," he added.
But Kasyanov said Russia would not join the Paris Club if the price was wrong.
He said Russia was looking at problem countries not wishing to undergo a Paris Club debt restructuring plan and would decide later how to settle problems, including securitising some debt.
He said Russia in owed about $120 billion in its own right, $100 billion of inherited from the Soviet Union.
Russia owes Paris Club states $40 billion and it rescheduled the debts for up to 25 years in 1995.
It owes about $35 billion to the London Club of commercial bank creditors, but these loans have also been rescheduled.
Kasyanov said Russia had been extending about $0.5 billion annually in credits since 1994. "Now the major idea is not to give money to those who do not pay back," he said.
